revision.text:
The '''2010 MFA Cup final''' took place on 18 December 2010 at the [[Stade Germain Comarmond|Germain Comarmond stadium]]http://lemauricien.com/mauricien/101220/sp.htm#1 in Mauritius. The match was contested by [[AS de Vacoas-Phoenix]] and [[Pointe aux Sables Mates]]. AS de Vacoas-Phoenix won the final 1-0. == Match == {{footballbox |date=18 December 2010 |time= |team1=[[AS de Vacoas-Phoenix]] |score=1 - 0 |penalties1 = |penaltyscore = |penalties2 = |report= |team2=[[Pointe aux Sables Mates]] |goals1= Jean-François Nadal {{goal|10}} |goals2= |stadium=[[Stade Germain Comarmond]], Bambous |attendance= |referee=Gunesh Chuttoree }}
{| style="margin-left:268px; width:535px" |- | '''AS de Vacoas-Phoenix''' || '''Pointe aux Sables Mates''' |- | Ivahn Marie Josée || Kersley Auguste |- | Marco Dorza {{yel|87}} || Jason Vythilingum |- | Jean-Pierre Cerveaux ([[Captain (association football)|c]]) || Kervin Rita {{yel|85}} {{sent off|0|89}} |- | Kersley Levrai || Thierry François |- | Jean-Karl Augustin || Joye Estazie ([[Captain (association football)|c]]) |- | William Gaspard {{suboff|85}} || Julio Milazare {{suboff|87}} |- | Felix Sai || Hailey Appadoo {{suboff|54}} |- | Aslam Abdullah {{yel|85}} {{sent off|0|90}} || Rico Shocktorap |- | Roddy Edwards {{yel|81}} || Zola Raveloarison |- | Jean-François Nadal {{goal|10}} {{suboff|71}} || Rijaitainana {{suboff|65}} |- | Ben Abdallah || Jean-Reck Ah-Fock |- | || |- | '''Substitutes:''' || '''Substitutes:''' |- | Julien Salomon {{subon|71}} || Rony Raboude {{subon|54}} |- | Kevin François {{subon|85}} || Stevenson Clair {{subon|65}} |- | || Jason Mohangee {{subon|87}} |- | || |- | '''Coach :''' || '''Coach :''' |- | Maurice Andriamandranto || Bruno Randrianarivony |} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Mauritian Cup]] [[Category:2010 in Mauritian football|Cup]] {{Mauritius-sport-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{lead too short|date=August 2011}} The '''2011 [[Turkmenistan Cup]]''' is 19th since independence of the [[Turkmenistan|Turkmen]] national [[Association football|football]] cup. ==Quarterfinals== The quarterfinal involves 8 best teams of previous regular season. {{TwoLegStart}} {{TwoLegResult|[[FC Balkan]]||1 – 2|'''[[FC Lebap]]'''||0 – 1|1 – 1}} {{TwoLegResult|'''[[FC Aşgabat]]'''||2 – 3|[[FC Altyn Asyr]]||1 – 1|2 – 1}} {{TwoLegResult|'''[[HTTU Aşgabat]]'''||3 – 3 (4 – 2[[Penalty shootout (association football)|p]])|[[FC Şagadam]]||2 – 1|1 – 2}} {{TwoLegResult|'''[[FC Merw]]'''||9 – 1|[[FC Ahal]]||4 – 0|5 – 1}} |} ===First leg=== {{footballbox |date= 2 August 2011 |time= |team1=[[FC Balkan]] |score= 0 – 1 |team2=[[FC Lebap]] |goals1= |goals2=[[Rahmet Şermetow|Şermetow]] {{goal|29}} |stadium=[[Balkanabat Stadium]], [[Balkanabat]] |attendance= |referee= }} ---- {{footballbox |date= 2 August 2011 |time= |team1=[[FC Aşgabat]] |score= 1 – 1 |team2=[[FC Altyn Asyr]] |goals1= [[Döwletmyrat Ataýew|Ataýew]] {{goal|60}} |goals2= [[Pirmyrat Gazakow|Gazakow]] {{goal|55}} |stadium=[[Nisa-Çandybil Stadium]], [[Ashgabat]] |attendance= |referee= }} ---- {{footballbox |date= 2 August 2011 |time= |team1=[[HTTU Aşgabat]] |score= 2 – 1 |team2=[[FC Şagadam]] |goals1=[[Gahrymanberdi Çoňkaýew|Çaňkaýew]] {{goal|11}}
[[Mämmedaly Garadanow|Garadanow]] {{goal|90+2}} |goals2=[[Aleksandr Boliýan|Boliýan]] {{goal|58}} |stadium=[[HTTU Stadium]], [[Ashgabat]] |attendance= |referee= }} ---- {{footballbox |date= 2 August 2011 |time= |team1=[[FC Merw]] |score= 4 – 0 |team2=[[FC Ahal]] |goals1=[[Jemşit Orazmuhammedow|Orazmuhammedow]] {{goal|3}}

revision.text:
{{Year box}} {{Year nav topic5|2014|combat sports}} {{about|the 2014 combat sports season and results|other sports' results|2014 in sports}}
==[[Amateur boxing]]== * April 10 – 25: 2014 [[AIBA Youth World Boxing Championships]] in {{flagicon|BUL}} [[Sofia]]<ref>[http://www.boxingsofia2014.org/ AIBA Sofia 2014 Page]</ref><ref>[http://boxingsofia2014.org/download/C74E50.pdf Sofia 2014 Youth World Boxing Championships Final Results]</ref> ** Men's light fly winner: {{flagicon|KAZ}} Shalkar Aikhynbay ** Men's fly winner: {{flagicon|USA}} Shakur Stevenson ** Men's bantam winner: {{flagicon|CUB}} Javier Ibanez ** Men's light winner: {{flagicon|KAZ}} Ablaikhan Zhussupov ** Men's light welter winner: {{flagicon|RUS}} Bibert Tumenov ** Men's welter winner: {{flagicon|UZB}} Bektemir Melikuziev ** Men's middle winner: {{flagicon|RUS}} Dmitrii Nesterov ** Men's light heavy winner: {{flagicon|BUL}} Blagoy Naydenov ** Men's heavy winner: {{flagicon|CUB}} Yordan Hernandez ** Men's super heavy winner: {{flagicon|USA}} Daramni Rock ** Women's fly winner: {{flagicon|ARM}} Anush Grigoryan ** Women's light winner: {{flagicon|USA}} Jajaira Gonzalez ** Women's middle winner: {{flagicon|POL}} Elzbieta Wojcik * August 23 – 27: [[Boxing at the 2014 Summer Youth Olympics|2014 Summer Youth Olympics]]<ref>[http://mat1.gtimg.com/nanjing2014/resultsbook/Results_Book_BX_V1.0.pdf Nanjing 2014 Boxing Complete Result Book]</ref> ** {{flagIOC|CUB|2014 Summer Youth|}} and the {{flagIOC|USA|2014 Summer Youth|}} won 2 gold medals each. Cuba, the USA, and {{flagIOC|ITA|2014 Summer Youth|}} won 3 overall medals each. * November 13 – 25: [[2014 AIBA Women's World Boxing Championships]] in {{flagicon|KOR}} [[Jeju City]]<ref>[http://www.aiba.org/en-US/news/ozqsp/newsId/5805/headlines.aspx Jeju 2014 AIBA Headline]</ref> ** {{RUS}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies.
==[[Fencing]]== * January 16 – October 26: [[2013–14 Fencing World Cup]]<ref>[http://www.fie.ch/Competitions/CalendarPrint.aspx?param=9E53FCFB9A3D65977B4DAD2D62E117B6 2013–14 FIE Calendar]</ref> * June 1 – 6: [[2014 Pan American Fencing Championships]] in {{flagicon|CRC}} [[San José, Costa Rica|San José]] ** Men's Individual Épée winner: {{flagicon|VEN}} [[Francisco Limardo]] ** Men's Individual Foil winner: {{flagicon|USA}} [[Gerek Meinhardt]] ** Men's Individual Sabre winner: {{flagicon|USA}} [[Eli Dershwitz]] ** Men's Team Épée winners: {{CUB}} ** Men's Team Foil winners: {{USA}} ** Men's Team Sabre winner: {{USA}} ** Women's Individual Épée winner: {{flagicon|USA}} [[Lee Kiefer]] ** Women's Individual Épée winner: {{flagicon|USA}} [[Courtney Hurley]] ** Women's Individual Sabre winner: {{flagicon|ARG}} [[María Belén Pérez Maurice]] ** Women's Team Épée winners: {{USA}} ** Women's Team Foil winners: {{USA}} ** Women's Team Sabre winners: {{USA}} ** The {{USA}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies. * June 7 – 14: [[2014 European Fencing Championships]] in {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Strasbourg]] ** {{ITA}} won the gold medal tally. {{RUS}} won the overall medal tally. * June 20 – 24: 2014 African Fencing Championships in {{flagicon|EGY}} [[Cairo]]<ref>[http://www.fie.ch/Competitions/ResultsListDetail.aspx?param=88BEB343F3E3E866FC04BBDE8707A50FA6258D65DD7258D8467BF9DE34F546F029050385D6D125943478397397074B33869B431BC0729404A6F540BBE9BC9BAC Cairo 2014 FIE Results]</ref> ** Host nation, {{EGY}}, and {{TUN}} won 6 gold medals each. However, Egypt won the overall medal tally. * July 2 – 7: 2014 [[2014 Asian Fencing Championships]] in {{flagicon|KOR}} [[Suwon]]<ref>[http://www.fie.ch/Competitions/ResultsListDetail.aspx?param=DA9F1BFC152F2205B3C65F2DFA3E5783C9427ABD9C238E4CE61E3DCB1D0BE929869B431BC0729404A6F540BBE9BC9BAC Suwon 2014 FIE Results]</ref> ** Host nation, {{KOR}}, won both the gold and overall medal tallies. * July 15 – 23: [[2014 World Fencing Championships]] in {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Kazan]]<ref>[http://www.kzn2014.com/en Kazan 2014 World Fencing Championships Website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140313112226/http://kzn2014.com/en |date=2014-03-13 }}</ref> ** {{FRA}}, {{ITA}}, and host nation, {{RUS}}, won 3 gold medals each. Italy and Russia won 8 overall medals each. * August 17 – 20: [[Fencing at the 2014 Summer Youth Olympics|2014 Summer Youth Olympics]]<ref>[http://mat1.gtimg.com/nanjing2014/resultsbook/Results_Book_FE_V1.0.pdf Nanjing 2014 Fencing Complete Result Book]</ref> ** Boys' Individual Sabre: {{gold01}} {{flagicon|RUS}} Ivan Ilin; {{silver02}} {{flagicon|KOR}} Kim Dong-ju; {{bronze03}} {{flagicon|CHN}} Yan Yinghui ** Boys' Individual Épée: {{gold01}} {{flagicon|HUN}} Patrik Esztergályos; {{silver02}} {{flagicon|SWE}} Linus Islas Flygare; {{bronze03}} {{flagicon|RUS}} Ivan Limarev ** Boys' Individual Foil: {{gold01}} {{flagicon|POL}} Andrzej Rządkowsk; {{silver02}} {{flagicon|HKG}} Ryan Chun Yin Choi; {{bronze03}} {{flagicon|FRA}} Enguerrand Roger ** Girls' Individual Foil: {{gold01}} {{flagicon|USA}} Sabrina Massialas; {{silver02}} {{flagicon|JPN}} Karin Miyawaki; {{bronze03}} {{flagicon|CHN}} Huang Ali ** Girls' Individual Épée: {{gold01}} {{flagicon|KOR}} Lee Sin-hee; {{silver02}} {{flagicon|ITA}} Eleonora de Marchi; {{bronze03}} {{flagicon|SWE}} Åsa Linde ** Girls' Individual Sabre: {{gold01}} {{flagicon|RUS}} Alina Moseyko; {{silver02}} {{flagicon|ITA}} Chiara Crovari; {{bronze03}}{{flagicon|HUN}} Petra Záhonyi ** Mixed Continental Team: {{gold01}} Team Asia-Oceania One; {{silver02}} Team Europe One; {{bronze03}} Team Europe Two * October 21 – 26: 2014 FIE World Masters Championships in {{flagicon|HUN}} [[Debrecen]]<ref>[http://www.veteranfencingwch2014.com/Results/ Debrecen 2014 FIE World Masters Championships Medal Tally]</ref> ** {{ITA}} and the {{USA}} won 5 gold medals each. {{GER}} won the overall medal tally.
==[[Judo]]== * January 25 – December 7: [http://www.intjudo.eu/upload/2014_03/08/139430383733204689/ijf_calendar_2014_(version_2014_03_06).pdf 2014 International Judo Federation Calendar of Events] * January 25 – November 9: 2014 AJU African Open ** January 25 & 26: 2014 African Open #1 in {{flagicon|MAR}} [[Casablanca]]<ref>[http://www.alljudo.net/resultats-judo-3320-african-open-seniors-mf-casablanca-2014.html AllJudo.com 2014 African Open Results]</ref> *** {{FRA}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies. ** November 8 & 9: 2014 African Open #2 (final) in {{flagicon|MRI}} [[Port Louis]]<ref>[http://www.judoinside.com/event/9621 Port Louis 2014 African Open Page]</ref> *** {{ALG}} and {{GBR2}} won 3 gold medals each. Algeria won the overall medal tally. * February 1 – October 5: 2014 EJU European Open ** February 1 & 2: 2014 European Open #1 in {{flagicon|BUL}} [[Sofia]] *** {{GER}}, {{HUN}}, and {{ISR}} all tied with 2 gold medals each. {{UKR}} won the overall medal tally.<ref>[http://www.eju.net/results/?mode=showResult&id=1613 Sofia 2014 European Open Results Page]</ref> ** February 15 & 16: 2014 European Open #2 in {{flagicon|AUT}} [[Oberwart]] *** {{JPN}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies.<ref>[http://www.ippon.org/cont_open_aut2014.php Oberwart 2014 European Open Medal Tally]</ref> ** February 15 & 16: 2014 European Open #3 in {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Rome]] *** {{JPN}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies.<ref>[http://www.ippon.org/cont_open_ita2014.php Rome 2014 European Open Medal Tally]</ref> ** March 1 & 2: 2014 European Open #4 in {{flagicon|CZE}} [[Prague]]<ref>[http://www.ippon.org/cont_open_cze2014.php Prague 2014 European Open Medal Tally]</ref> *** Seven different nations all share 1 gold medal each. However, {{HUN}} won the overall medal tally. ** March 1 & 2: 2014 European Open #5 in {{flagicon|POL}} [[Warsaw]]<ref>[http://www.ippon.org/cont_open_pol2014.php Warsaw 2014 European Open Page]</ref> *** Seven different nations all share 1 gold medal each. However, {{FRA}} won the overall medal tally. ** May 31 & June 1: 2014 European Open #6 in {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Madrid]]<ref>[http://judolive01.lb.judobase.org/www.judo-world.net/eju/european_open/2014_madrid/tta_menue_eju.php?modus=1024&sprache=English Madrid 2014 European Open Page]</ref> *** {{CHN}}, {{ITA}}, {{NED}}, and {{UKR}} won 2 gold medals each. However, {{FRA}} won the overall medal tally. ** September 27 & 28: 2014 European Open #7 in {{flagicon|EST}} [[Tallinn]]<ref>[http://www.ippon.org/cont_open_est2014.php Tallinn 2014 European Open Page]</ref> *** The {{NED}} won the gold medal tally. {{RUS}} won the overall medal tally. ** October 4: 2014 European Open #8 (final and women only) in {{flagicon|GBR}} [[Glasgow]]<ref>[http://www.ippon.org/cont_open_gbr2014.php Glasgow 2014 European Open Page (Women)]</ref> *** {{JPN}} won the gold medal tally. {{FRA}}, {{GER}}, and Japan won 7 overall medals each. ** October 4 & 5: 2014 European Open #9 (final and men only) in {{flagicon|POR}} [[Lisbon]]<ref>[http://www.ippon.org/cont_open_por2014.php Lisbon 2014 European Open Page (Men)]</ref> *** {{JPN}} won the gold medal tally. Japan and host nation, {{POR}}, won 5 overall medals each. * February 8 – December 7: 2014 [[International Judo Federation|IJF]] Judo Grand Slam ** February 8 & 9 at {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Paris]]<ref>[http://www.ippon.org/gs_fra2014.php Paris 2014 Medal Table]</ref> *** {{JPN}} won the gold medal tally. Host nation, {{FRA}}, won the overall medal tally. ** May 9 – 11 at {{flagicon|AZE}} [[Baku]]<ref>[http://www.ippon.org/gs_aze2014.php Baku 2014 Medal Table]</ref> *** {{FRA}} won the gold medal tally. {{RUS}} won the overall medal tally. ** July 12 & 13 at {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Tyumen]]<ref>[http://www.judobase.org/#/competition/profile/1167/medal_ranking Tyumen 2014 Medal Table]</ref> *** {{JPN}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies. ** October 31 – November 2 at {{flagicon|UAE}} [[Abu Dhabi]]<ref>[http://www.judobase.org/#/competition/profile/1181/medal_ranking Abu Dhabi Medal Table]</ref> *** {{GER}} won the gold and overall medal tallies. ** December 5 – 7 at {{flagicon|JPN}} [[Tokyo]] (final GS)<ref>[http://www.judobase.org/#/competition/profile/1187/medal_ranking Tokyo 2014 Grand Slam Medal Standing]</ref> *** Host nation, {{JPN}}, won both the gold and overall medal tallies. * February 21 – November 29: 2014 IJF Judo Grand Prix ** February 21 – 23 at {{flagicon|GER}} [[Düsseldorf]]<ref>[http://www.ippon.org/gp_ger2014.php Düsseldorf 2014 Grand Prix Medal Tally]</ref> *** {{JPN}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies. ** March 21 – 23 at {{flagicon|GEO}} [[Tbilisi]]<ref>[http://198.71.59.59/www.judo-world.net/ijf/grand_prix/2014_tbilisi/tta.php?tta_mode=&aktion=medals&geschlecht=&sprache=english Tbilisi 2014 Grand Prix Medal Tally]</ref> *** Host nation, {{GEO}}, won both the gold and overall medal tallies. ** March 28 – 30 at {{flagicon|TUR}} [[Samsun]]<ref>[http://198.71.59.59/www.judo-world.net/ijf/grand_prix/2014_samsun/tta.php?tta_mode=&aktion=medals&geschlecht=&sprache=English Samsun 2014 Grand Prix Medal Tally]</ref> *** {{GER}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies. ** June 6 – 8 at {{flagicon|CUB}} [[Havana]]<ref>[http://www.ippon.org/gp_cub2014.php Havana 2014 Grand Prix Live Results Page]</ref> *** {{GEO}} won the gold medal tally. {{CUB}} and {{RUS}} won 8 overall medals each. ** June 21 & 22 at {{flagicon|HUN}} [[Budapest]]<ref>[http://www.ippon.org/gp_hun2014.php Budapest 2014 Grand Prix Live Results Page]</ref> *** {{JPN}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies. ** July 4 – 6 at {{flagicon|MGL}} [[Ulaanbaatar]]<ref>[http://www.ippon.org/gp_mgl2014.php Ulaanbaatar 2014 Grand Prix Live Results Page]</ref> *** Both {{JPN}} and host nation, {{MGL}}, tied in the gold and overall medal tallies. ** September 12 – 14 at {{flagicon|CRO}} [[Zagreb]]<ref>[http://www.ippon.org/gp_cro2014.php Zagreb 2014 Grand Prix Live Results Page]</ref> *** Four nations won two gold medals each. Four nations won four overall medals each. ** October 10 – 12 at {{flagicon|KAZ}} [[Astana]]<ref>[http://www.ippon.org/gp_kaz2014.php Astana 2014 Grand Prix Live Results Page]</ref> *** {{HUN}} and host nation, {{KAZ}}, won 2 gold medals each. However, {{GER}} won the overall medal tally. ** October 16 – 18 at {{flagicon|UZB}} [[Tashkent]]<ref>[http://www.ippon.org/gp_uzb2014.php Tashkent 2014 Grand Prix Live Results Page]</ref> *** {{MGL}} won both the gold and overall medal talllies. ** November 19 – 21 at {{flagicon|CHN}} [[Qingdao]]<ref>[http://www.judoinside.com/event/9603 Qingdao 2014 Grand Prix Page]</ref> *** {{RUS}} won the gold medal tally. {{JPN}} won the overall medal tally. ** November 27 – 29 at {{flagicon|KOR}} [[Jeju City]] (final)<ref>[http://www.judobase.org/#/competition/profile/1186/medal_ranking Jeju City 2014 Grand Prix Medals Page]</ref> *** Host nation, {{KOR}}, and {{FRA}} won 6 gold medals each. South Korea won the overall medal tally. * March 8 – May 18: 2014 EJU Cadets Series ** March 8 & 9: 2014 EJU Cadets #1 in {{flagicon|CRO}} [[Zagreb]]<ref>[http://216.250.117.142/www.judo-world.net/eju/european_cup/ecup_cad_zagreb2014/tta_menue_eju.php?modus=1024&sprache=English Zagreb 2014 Cadets Medal Tally]</ref> *** {{GER}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies. ** March 17 – 19: 2014 EJU Cadets #2 in {{flagicon|TUR}} [[Antalya]]<ref>[http://216.250.117.142/www.judo-world.net/eju/european_cup/ecup_cad_antalya2014/tta_menue_eju.php?modus=1024&sprache=english Antalya 2014 Cadets Medal Tally]</ref> *** {{RUS}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies. ** March 29 & 30: 2014 EJU Cadets #3 in {{flagicon|UKR}} [[Kiev]] *** Status: Cancelled, due to the [[2014 Crimean crisis]]. ** April 5 & 6: 2014 EJU Cadets #4 in {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Tver]]<ref>[http://198.71.59.59/www.judo-world.net/eju/european_cup/ecup_cad_tver2014/tta_menue_eju.php?modus=1024&sprache=English Tver 2014 Cadets Medal Tally]</ref> *** Host nation, {{RUS}}, won both the gold and overall medal tallies. ** April 12 & 13: 2014 EJU Cadets #5 in {{flagicon|POR}} [[Coimbra]]<ref>[http://198.71.59.59/www.judo-world.net/eju/european_cup/ecup_cad_coimbra2014/tta_menue_eju.php?modus=1024&sprache=English Coimbra 2014 Cadets Page]</ref> *** {{GER}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies. ** April 26 & 27: 2014 EJU Cadets #6 in {{flagicon|ROU}} [[Pitești]]<ref>[http://www.eju.net/results/?mode=showResult&id=1693 Pitești 2014 Cadets Page]</ref> *** {{TUR}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies. ** May 3 & 4: 2014 EJU Cadets #7 in {{flagicon|GER}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = ASC Police| image = | fullname = Association Sportive et Culturelle de la Police | nickname = | founded = | ground = [[Stade Olympique (Nouakchott)]]
[[Nouakchott]], [[Mauritania]] | capacity = 10,000| chairman = | manager = | league = [[Mauritanean Premier League]] | season = 2013-14 | position = | }} '''Association Sportive et Culturelle de la Police''' ({{lang-ar|الجمعية الرياضية و الثقافية للشرطة}}) is a [[Mauritania|Mauritanean]] [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Nouakchott]]. The club plays in the [[Mauritanean Premier League]],https://int.soccerway.com/teams/mauritania/asc-police/10295/matches/ which it won in 1981.http://www.rsssf.com/tablesm/maurchamp.html ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the 10,000 capacity [[Stade Olympique (Nouakchott)]]. ==Honours== *'''[[Mauritanean Premier League]]''' ::Champion (7): 1981, 1982, 1986, 1987, 1988, 1990, 1991 *'''[[Coupe du Président de la République]]''' ::Winner (2): 1985, 1999 ==Performance in CAF competitions== *'''[[CAF Champions League]]: 1 appearance''' ::[[1983 African Cup of Champions Clubs|1983]] – First Round ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.footballdatabase.eu/football.club.asc-police..13370..en.html Team profile] - ''footballdatabase.eu'' *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/mauritania/asc-police/10295 Team profile] - ''soccerway.com'' {{Mauritanean Premier League}} {{Mauritania-footyclub-stub}} [[Category:Football clubs in Mauritania]] [[Category:Sport in Nouakchott]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Banner Island Ballpark | nickname = ''Stockton Ballpark'' | image = [[File:BIBField.JPG|center|300px]] | location = 404 West Fremont Street
[[Stockton, California]]
[[United States]] | coordinates = {{coord|37|57|17.48|N|121|17|52.64|W|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = April 17, 2004{{cite web |title=Banner Island Ballpark History|url=http://www.minorleaguebaseball.com/team1/page.jsp?ymd=20081120&content_id=482097&vkey=team1_t524&fext=.jsp&sid=t524|publisher=Minor League Baseball|date=November 20, 2008|accessdate=March 4, 2014}} | opened = April 28, 2005 | owner = [[Stockton, California|City of Stockton]] | operator = [[SMG (property management)|SMG]] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]22 Million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|22000000|2005}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = [[HKS, Inc.]] | services engineer = Frank M. Booth, Inc.{{cite web |title=Stockton Ball Park|url=http://www.frankbooth.com/project/project-detail.php?proj_id=107|publisher=Frank M. Booth, Inc.|accessdate=March 4, 2014}} | project_manager = McCuskey Group{{cite web |title=Project Portfolio|url=http://mccuskeygroup.com/projectportfolio.htm|publisher=The McCuskey Group|accessdate=March 4, 2014}} | general_contractor = [[Swinerton|Swinerton Builders]]{{cite news |title=Swinerton Completes New Waterfront Ballpark|url=http://california.construction.com/news/contracts/archive/0507.asp|newspaper=California Construction|date=July 2005|accessdate=November 6, 2011}} | tenants = [[Stockton Ports]] ([[California League|CL]]) (2005–present) | seating_capacity = 5,200 (baseball) | dimensions = '''Left Field:''' {{Convert|300|ft|m}}
'''Center Field:''' {{Convert|399|ft|m}}
'''Right Field:''' {{Convert|326|ft|m}} |publictransit={{rint|us|amtrak}} [[San Joaquin Street station|Stockton – San Joaquin Street]] {{rint|us|amtrak}} {{rint|ace}} [[Robert J. Cabral Station|Stockton – Downtown Station]]}} '''Banner Island Ballpark''' is a [[baseball]] [[stadium]] located in [[Stockton, California]], which seats 5,200 people with 4,200 fixed seats. It is the home field of the [[Stockton Ports]], a [[minor league baseball|minor league]] affiliate of the [[Oakland Athletics]] in the Class A [[California League]]. ==History== The $22 million Banner Island Ballpark opened with a baseball game on April 28, 2005, during which the Stockton Ports defeated the [[San Jose Giants]], 7–4, in front of a sellout crowd of 5,287 fans.{{cite news |title=Time to Play Ball|first=Jagdip|last=Dhillon|url=http://www.recordnet.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20050428/SPORTS/504280314|newspaper=[[The Record (Stockton)]]|date=April 28, 2005|accessdate=May 31, 2014}}{{cite news |title=A Banner Ballpark|first=Ross|last=McKeon|url=http://www.sfgate.com/sports/article/A-Banner-Ballpark-Stockton-s-cozy-new-stadium-2638147.php|newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=April 30, 2005|accessdate=May 31, 2014}} The ballpark is a part of a revitalization project for the Downtown Stockton waterfront. It was built concurrently with the [[Stockton Arena]] and will be integrated with a waterfront park. The Banner Island area is also the purported home of a previous Stockton baseball team that played in the late 1800s. Local residents claim that the team was the inspiration for the Mudville Nine in "[[Casey at the Bat]]", a poem by [[Ernest Thayer]]. Before moving to the ballpark, the Stockton Ports were known as the Mudville Nine during the 2000 and 2001 seasons. ==Name== [[File:BIBEntrance.JPG|thumb|left|200px|Ballpark Entrance; note the signage that says "Stockton Ballpark"]] The name "Banner Island Ballpark" is actually an unofficial name that is used among fans and the administration of the Stockton Ports. The City of Stockton owns the naming rights of the ballpark and until the rights are sold the stadium is officially known as '''Stockton Ballpark'''.{{cite web|title=Banner Island Ballpark |first=Joe |last=Mock |url=http://www.baseballparks.com/stockton.asp |work=Baseball Parks |accessdate=March 4, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141116212238/http://www.baseballparks.com/Stockton.asp |archivedate=November 16, 2014 |df= }} The ballpark gets its unofficial name from the area in which it is located, Banner Island. This was once an island in the [[San Joaquin River]] [[river delta|delta]], noted during the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] for the huge "Stars and Stripes" posted by a Union supporter. In time the island was connected to the mainland through [[land reclamation|land fill]] and only the southern shore remains. Despite the fact the area is no longer an island, the Banner Island name has stuck. {{Clear}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.stocktonports.com/ballpark/history/ Stockton Ports Ballpark History] *[http://www.stocktonlive.com/venues/detail/stockton-ballpark SMG Stockton: Stockton Ballpark] *[http://www.ballparkreviews.com/stockton/banner.htm ballparkreviews.com] Banner Island Ballpark *[http://www.littleballparks.com/Stadium/2008/Stockton/Stockton.htm Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues] Banner Island Ballpark Views *[http://www.stadiumjourney.com/stadiums/banner-island-ballpark-s336/images Stockton Ports] Stadium Journey-Banner Island Ballpark {{California League Ballparks}} [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Baseball venues in California]] [[Category:2005 establishments in California]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2005]]

{{Infobox American football team | name = Corinthians Steamrollers | logo = | logosize = | established = 2004 | location = [[São Paulo]], [[São Paulo (state)|SP]], Brazil | stadium = 13,969-capacity [[Estádio Parque São Jorge]] | coach = Fabio Marin Jr. | president = Ricardo Trigo São Paulo Football League - Corinthians Steamrollers http://www.spflbrasil.com/#!corinthians-steamrollers/y8f8y | league = [[São Paulo Football League]],Official Website of the SPFL http://www.spflbrasil.com [[Confederação Brasileira de Futebol Americano]] | colors = Black and White
{{Color box|#000000}} {{Color box|#FFFFFF}} | league_champs = 2011, 2012 | h_pattern_h = _af | h_pattern_la = | h_pattern_b = | h_pattern_ra = | h_pattern_p = | h_pattern_s = _whiteline | h_helmet = 000000 | h_leftarm = FFFFFF | h_body = FFFFFF | h_rightarm = FFFFFF | h_pants = 000000 | h_socks = 000000 | h_title = Home | a_pattern_h = _af | a_pattern_la = | a_pattern_b = _thinwhitesides | a_pattern_ra = | a_pattern_p = | a_pattern_s = _blackline | a_helmet = 000000 | a_leftarm = 222222 | a_body = 222222 | a_rightarm = 222222 | a_pants = FFFFFF | a_socks = 000000 | a_title = Away }} The '''Corinthians Steamrollers''' are a professional [[American football]] team competing in the South Conference of the [[Torneio Touchdown|Touchdown Tournament]]. Based in [[São Paulo]], Brazil the team was founded in 2004. The Steamrollers are associated with Brazil's powerhouse football club [[Sport Club Corinthians Paulista]]. The Steamrollers play their home games at '''[[Estádio Parque São Jorge|Estádio Parque São Jorge, or Fazendinha]]''' which opened in 1928 and holds 13,969 people. The Steamrollers have won the Touchdown Tournament twice (2011 and 2012) and have appeared in all but one edition of the tournament. The Steamrollers were undefeated both times during the years in which they have won the Touchdown Tournament In addition to the two national titles, the Steamrollers are four times São Paulo State Champions (2011, 2012, 2013 and 2014) going undefeated in the 2012, 2013 and 2014 titles. One of the Steamrollers largest feat was the Latin American tournament "Torneo Guerreros de los Andes" won in 2014. Between 2011 and 2012 the Steamrollers were in a 39-game winning streak. Currently, the team has 1,395,000 followers on [[Facebook]], making the team with most followers on Facebook in Brazil and with a number of followers greater than eight [[National Football League|NFL]] franchises. In March 2017, the team signed a jersey sponsorship with online entertainment brand Bodog. http://finance.yahoo.com/news/bodog-signs-shirt-sponsorship-corinthians-140000651.html == Current Staff == {| class="wikitable" !Name !Title !Position Coach |- |Fabio Marin Jr. |Head Coach |n/a |- |Alaor Peinado Jr. |Defensive Coordinator |Linebackers and Defensive Line |- |Vinicius Ribeiro |Offensive Coordinator |Quarterbacks and Receivers |- |Daniel Rocha |Assistant Coach |Offensive Line |- |José Luiz Seno |Assistant Coach |Defensive Backs |- |Jesse Haga |Assistant Coach |Running Backs |} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{cite web|title=Corinthians Steamrollers bate Vila Velha e aumenta série invicta para 39 jogos|url=http://www.corinthians.com.br/site/noticias/2013/07/15/10h32-id19769-corinthians-steamrollers-bate-vila-velha-e-aumenta-serie-invicta-para-39-jogos-.shtml|accessdate=30 August 2013|language=Portuguese}} [[Category:American football teams in Brazil|Corinthians]] [[Category:Sports clubs established in 2004]] [[Category:2004 establishments in Brazil]] {{Brazil-sport-stub}} {{Amfoot-team-stub}}

{{Infobox sports rivalry | name = | other names = | image = | caption = | city or region = [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]] | first contested = 1916{{cite web|url=http://www.svd.se/sport/samtliga-derbyresultat-bajen-dif_109382.svd|title=Samtliga derbyresultat Bajen-Dif | Sport | SvD|publisher=svd.se|accessdate=2014-04-06}} | teams involved = [[Djurgårdens IF Fotboll|Djurgårdens IF]]
[[Hammarby Fotboll|Hammarby IF]] | most wins = [[Djurgårdens IF Fotboll|Djurgårdens IF]] (49) | most player appearances = | top scorer = [[Jan Sjöström]], [[Hammarby Fotboll|Hammarby IF]] (12) | mostrecent = 29 April 2018
[[Djurgårdens IF Fotboll|Djurgårdens IF]]–[[Hammarby Fotboll|Hammarby IF]] (1–2{{cite web|url=https://svenskfotboll.se/allsvenskan/tabell-och-resultat/?scr=result&fmid=3795772|title=Allsvenskan, herrar Matchinformation: Djurgården mot Hammarby 2018-04-29 (1-2) — svenskfotboll.se|website=svenskfotboll.se|accessdate=4 June 2017}} | nextmeeting = 02 September 2018 | total = | league = | series = | regularseason = | postseason = | largestvictory =13 Augusti 1990
[[Djurgårdens IF Fotboll|Djurgårdens IF]]–[[Hammarby Fotboll|Hammarby IF]] (9–1) }} The fixture between [[Djurgårdens IF Fotboll|Djurgårdens IF]] and [[Hammarby Fotboll|Hammarby IF]] is a [[local derby]] in [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]]. This important football [[List of association football club rivalries by country|rivalry]] traces its origin back to the later half of the 1910s{{cn|date=August 2017}} but did not reach relevance until the 1950s and 60s.{{cn|date=August 2017}} There is a certain social aspect in the Hammarby - Djurgården rivalry. Hammarby consider [[Södermalm]], the southern, originally working-class, district of [[Stockholm City Centre]] where the club was founded, as well as the [[Söderort|boroughs just south of said district]], their heartland. Djurgården counts the affluent [[Östermalm]], the district that forms the eastern part of the [[Stockholm City Centre|city centre]], and where their former home ground [[Stockholms Stadion|Stadion]] is situated, as their stronghold. (Both clubs also maintain a cross-town rivalry with [[AIK Fotboll|AIK]], whose stronghold is the northwestern [[Stockholm urban area]], where their home ground is situated.) The two teams did not meet for five years (2010-2014) when Hammarby played in the second tier [[Superettan]] with Djurgården remaining in Allsvenskan. In 2013, both Djurgården and Hammarby moved into the newly built [[Tele2 Arena]] located in [[Johanneshov]], just south of the city centre. This increased tensions significantly between the two sets of fans. Since the return of Hammarby to the Swedish first tier, [[Allsvenskan]] in 2015, Djurgården has so far recorded six losses, two draws, but not a single win against Hammarby, in spite of an overall superior performance in the league. A similar dismal performance in the [[Tvillingderbyt | Djurgården – AIK Derby rivalry]] since 2011 was broken only in the [[Svenska cupen]] quarter final in March 2018. This has generated an infected debate among Djurgården fans about the team being affected by a Derby’s Curse (“Derbyspöket”, literally “The Derby ghost”). ==Matches== {{Updated|24 September 2017|{{cite web|url=http://www.svd.se/sport/samtliga-derbyresultat-bajen-dif_109382.svd|title=Samtliga derbyresultat Bajen-Dif|website=svd.se|accessdate=18 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=773&team2_id=1255&teamTabs=h2h|title=Djurgaardens's Head To Head Stats Against Any Team - Soccer Base|website=www.soccerbase.com|accessdate=18 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bolletinen.se/sfs/java/svcup.htm|title=Matcher i svenska cupen genom tiderna|website=www.bolletinen.se|accessdate=18 May 2017}} {{cite web|url=https://svenskfotboll.se/cuper-och-serier/svenska-cupen-herrar/grupp-6/|title=Tabell och resultat - Svenska Cupen, Grupp 6 — svenskfotboll.se|website=svenskfotboll.se|accessdate=18 May 2017}}}} {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; text-align: center" |- ! {{Infobox sport | name = Sri Lanka elle | image = Jude4.JPG | imagesize = 200px | caption = එල්ලය බලා වේගයෙන් පහරක් එල්ල කිරිම Sri Lanka elle - 1960 | union = Association of Sri Lanka Elle | first = [[Sri Lanka]] | first team = Gryhounds | registered = | clubs = | team = Sixteen players and four substitutes | mgender = Men and women elle team | category = | ball = Elle bat and ball | venue = Elle ground, paddy field or shore | olympic = Still not going to international level }}
'''Elle''' is a very popular Sri Lankan [[Bat-and-ball games|bat-and-ball game]], often played in rural villages and urban areas.involves a hitter, a pitcher and fielders. The hitter is given three chances to hit the ball pitched at him or her. Once the hitter hits the ball with the bat - often a sturdy [[bamboo]] stick, the hitter has to complete a round or run which includes about four possible "stoppings" spaced 55 meters apart. A strikeout happens if the hitter's ball is caught by the fielding side or if the fielding side is able to hit the hitter with the ball while he or she is in the course of completing a run. The hitter can stop only at one of the three stoppings in the round thereby paving the way for another member of his team to come and become the hitter. The side that gets the highest number of (complete) runs wins the match.
== History == Historians predict the game existed from around the 20th century and it is not clear by whom the Historigame of elle was introduced to Sri Lanka. Even though one cannot find definitive sources on the origin of the sport, there is evidence to suggest that the game predates the 20th century. The sport of elle in Sri Lanka goes back to more than two thousand years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ellesrilanka.blogspot.com|title=Sri Lanka Elle එල්ලේ|website=ellesrilanka.blogspot.com}}</ref> It is played among villagers during their free time in the evenings after work and especially close to the new year season; it was an interesting and competitive sport for the average person. [[File:Jude8.JPG|thumb|එල්ලේ පන්දුවට පහරදිම]] Simple yet sturdy sticks made the early bat while the improvised ball was sometimes a dried fruit of wel kaduru (''[[Cerbera manghas]]''). After reaping the harvest from their hard worked paddy fields farmers would gather together with their families by the now barren fields and play elle to celebrate the joy of a well earned break. [[File:Jude1.JPG|right|thumb|එල්ලේ පන්දුවට පහරදිම]]
An elle game was a communal activity enjoyed by the whole village, young and old, male and female alike. It was a time to enjoy, laugh and cheer on your loved ones and neighbors as the whole village would break into teams and play the game as a tournament. Elle would also be played as regional tournaments where teams representing adjacent villages or towns would battle to win the title of best elle team. This would gradually spread to national level championships played with good cheer.
[[Image:jude5.JPG|thumb|එල්ලේ තරගයක් Sri Lanka elle - 1960]] [[Image: jude6.JPG|thumb|එල්ලේ තරගයක් Sri Lanka elle - 1960]]
== Play == In a match, the maximum number of players in a team is sixteen with the minimum being twelve. The team with the lesser number would not usually call for the excess number of players to be removed from the opposing team. Instead the additional players in the larger team could be included in the line up prior to the commencement of the third innings. Striking or fielding could be decided upon by the [[Coin flipping|toss of a coin]]
== Elle ground == The playing area should be without obstructions especially to the running area. It should have an identical distance to the front and the two sides. The playing area should be marked with a line of 3 centimeters in breadth leaving at least five meters to the back of the striking spot.
Note: For matches played by school children the running distance between the bases would be less. Accordingly, for school matches the distance would be 11 m whereas for other matches arranged at sports society levels the distance would be 12 m.
== Materials == Equipment used in the playing area:
Two posts ten meters in height similar to a bamboo tree, six posts two centimeters in breadth and one meter in height and eight flags to be tied to the end of the posts. (The height of posts from ground level should be 1 meter.)
=== Elle bat === [[File:Jude1e.JPG|thumb|ප්‍රථමයෙන් භාවිතා කරන ලද පොල්පිත්ත]] The elle bat should be made out from well seasoned bamboo and the length and breadth of the bat can be in accordance with the requirements of the striker. Its circumference should not be changed under any circumstances. However, the elle bat could be bound with material without using any metal in order to protect it from breaking or being damaged.
=== Elle ball === Until such time as a special ball is specifically made for elle, [[tennis ball]]s are used. The fur on the ball could be removed/shaved before use but removing of fur to make the rubber visible is strictly prohibited. A rubber ball or another light ball could be used instead of a tennis ball, but it is of paramount importance that the ball used should be common to both teams.
== References == {{reflist}} *[http://www.srilankaelle.com/ Sri Lanka Elle] Official Web Page of Sri Lanka Elle * *[http://www.srilankaelle.com/ එලලය] About Sport Of Sri Lanka Elle]-S Jude Silva No 56 B Thibbotugoda,Ganemulla First time Edited Web Page for Sri Lanka Elle - In Year 2000 * [https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCGyhCn52ork3QWb0UlCy-OA// About Sport Of Sri Lanka Elle]-S Jude Silva No 56 B Thibbotugoda,Ganemulla Firse time Edited Videos for Sri Lanka Elle - In Year 2000
[[Category:Traditional Sri Lankan sports]] [[Category:Ball and bat games]] [[Category:Team sports]] __INDEX__

{{Infobox stadium | name = Estadio BBVA Bancomer | former_names = | logo_image = Estadio de Fútbol Monterrey.png | image = Estadio BBVA Bancomer (1).jpg | image_size = 250px | fullname = | location = [[Guadalupe, Nuevo León]], Mexico | coordinates = {{coord|25|40|9|N|100|14|40|W|display=it}} | publictransit = | built = 2011–2015 | opened = August 2, 2015 | status = Bowl construction and outfitting | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[FEMSA]] | operator = [[FEMSA]] | executive suites = 300 | surface = Grass | construction_cost = US$200 million[http://stadiumdb.com/constructions/mex/estadio_de_futbol_monterrey stadiumdb.com - Estadio de Fútbol Monterrey] | architect = [[Populous (company)|Populous / VFO / Federico Velasco]] | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = Aceros Lozano, GGP, Maíz Mier | tenants = [[C.F. Monterrey|Monterrey]] (2015–present) | capacity = 51,000 (2015 opening)
53,500 (2016 expansion) | record_attendance = | dimensions = 265x223 | scoreboard = | website = [http://www.estadiobbvabancomer.com/ Website] }} The '''Estadio BBVA Bancomer''', nicknamed "El Gigante de Acero" (Spanish for "The Steel Giant"), is a stadium developed by [[FEMSA]] and [[C.F. Monterrey]] in [[Guadalupe, Nuevo León|Guadalupe]], [[Monterrey Metropolitan area|Greater Monterrey]]. The stadium replaced the [[Estadio Tecnológico]] as the home of Monterrey, ending 63 years of residency at that stadium. The project was met with much controversy, stemming from multiple accusations of the construction as an apparent impediment to wildlife growth on a local scale.{{Why|date=June 2018}} http://www.greenpeace.org/mexico/es/Noticias/2011/Octubre/No-acaben-con-el-ultimo-pulmon-de-Monterrey-ONG/ It was inaugurated on 2 August 2015 with the eighth edition of the [[Eusébio Cup]], where Monterrey defeated [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] 3–0.{{cite web |url=http://www.slbenfica.pt/noticias/detalhedenoticia/tabid/2788/ArticleId/42197/language/pt-PT/.aspx |title=Eusébio Cup no México |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Eusébio Cup in Mexico |date=23 June 2015 |publisher=[[S.L. Benfica]] |access-date=23 June 2015}}{{cite news|title=Rayados goleó a Benfica en inauguración|url=http://www.mediotiempo.com/futbol/mexico/cronicas/2015/08/03/rayados-goleo-a-benfica-en-inauguracion_64408|publisher=Medio Tiempo|date=2 August 2015|language=Spanish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150805203128/http://www.mediotiempo.com/futbol/mexico/cronicas/2015/08/03/rayados-goleo-a-benfica-en-inauguracion_64408|archivedate=5 August 2015|df=}} == Design== [[Populous (company)|Populous]], a multinational architecture firm, along with the mexican architecture firm V&FO and [[:es:Federico_Velasco|Federico Velasco]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.archdaily.com/898692/the-stadiums-that-could-host-the-2026-world-cup-in-the-us-canada-and-mexico|title=The Stadiums That Could Host the 2026 World Cup in the US, Canada, and Mexico|last=Dobbins|first=Tom|date=14 August 2018|website=Arch Daily|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}; were responsibles for the design and project lead since 2008 {{cite web|url=http://www.worldarchitecturenews.com/index.php?fuseaction=wanappln.projectview&upload_id=10814|title=HOK Sport reveal glowing windmill design|work=worldarchitecturenews.com|date=2 December 2008|accessdate=10 May 2012|language=inglés}} {{cite web|url=http://www.heraldoleon.mx/la-aficion-de-leon-se-merece-un-mejor-estadio-diego-sinhue/|title=“La afición de León se merece un mejor estadio”|work= Heraldo el Bajío|accessdate= June 5, 2018|language=español}}{{cite web | title = Estadio del Tecnológico: si los muros hablaran | url = http://tecreview.itesm.mx/estadio-del-tecnologico-si-los-muros-hablaran/ | |work= Tecnológico de Monterrey |author= F. Rubio |date= 7 December 2015|accessdate= 2 December 2017 }} {{cite web|url=https://www.vanguardia.com.mx/articulo/inicia-la-demolicion-del-estadio-del-tec|title=Inicia la demolición del Estadio del Tec|work=VanguardiaMX|author=Óscar Morín |date=3 July 2017|accessdate=28 February 2018|language=español}} The stadium was opened in 2015 with a capacity of 51,000 people, the fourth largest in Mexico. The owners soon added more seats, expanding the capacity to 53,500 in 2016.{{cite news |url=http://www.mediotiempo.com/futbol/mexico/noticias/2016/01/08/estadio-de-rayados-incremento-su-aforo |title=Estadio de Rayados incrementó su aforo |work=MedioTiempo.com |date=2016-01-08 |accessdate=2018-01-21}} It has a grass surface, suites, a club-themed restaurant, a club lounge, and high-end interior and exterior design.[http://www.mediotiempo.com/futbol/mexico/noticias/2016/01/08/estadio-de-rayados-incremento-su-aforo] The inclination of the grandstand is 34 degrees, and the distance between the field and seats is the minimum allowed by [[FIFA]], providing unsurpassed closeness to the action.{{cite web |url=http://www.multimedios.com/telediario/local/debes-nueva-casa-rayada.html |title=Lo que debes saber de la nueva casa rayada |language=Spanish |date=28 July 2015 |publisher=Multimedios |accessdate=2 August 2015}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Dimensions !! MTS. |- | Length || 277m |- | Wide || 232m |- | North side height || 46m |- | South side height || 32m |- | Circumference || 800m |} == Permeable area == More than a third of the total land area are green areas.{{cite news |url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/articulo/nacion/politica/2015/08/2/epn-estrena-estadio-de-rayados |title=EPN estrena estadio de Rayados |language=Spanish |date=2 August 2015 |publisher=[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]] |access-date=2 August 2015}} This proportion exceeds the current regulations. These green areas are used to filter rainwater, which will contribute to the recharge of aquifers. Parking lots are evenly distributed around the stadium, including wooded areas to achieve integration with the Ecological Park.{{cite web |url= https://45gradosmty.wordpress.com/2015/08/03/pros-y-contras-del-estadio-bbva-bancomer/ |title=Pros y contras del Estadio BBVA Bancomer |publisher=45mty|date=3 August 2015|language=Spanish|archivedate=3 August 2015|df=}} These areas are divided into zones, which are integrated into the landscape and topography. The northern boundary to the Rio La Silla is a wooded trail area that connects the stadium with the New Ecological Park.{{cite web |url=http://www.obrasweb.mx/construccion/2015/08/03/monterrey-se-raya-con-inauguracion-del-nuevo-estadio-bbva-bancomer |title=Monterrey 'se raya' con inauguración del nuevo Estadio BBVA Bancomer |language=Spanish |date=3 August 2015 |publisher=ObrasWeb.mx |access-date=3 August 2015}} This ecological park and parking are also green areas, with a landscape design that blends with the surrounding environment, with only trees and plants of the region to facilitate preservation and adaptation to the environment. ==References== {{Commons category|Estadio BBVA Bancomer}} {{Reflist}} ==External links== * * {{Official website|http://www.estadiodefutbolmonterrey.com/}} {{es icon}} {{en icon}} * [Official website Vergara y Fernandez de Ortega Arquitectos http://www.v-fo.com/] {{Liga MX venues}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Estadio De Futbol Monterrey}} [[Category:Sports venues in Monterrey]] [[Category:Football venues in Mexico]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2015]] {{Mexico-sports-venue-stub}}
